conclusion: Light beam is incident from air to sphere surface at angle i, travels through sphere, and is emitted into air.
Determine if light is totally reflected when emitted from inside sphere.
Snell's law applies at air-sphere interface: n_air sin i = n_sphere sin r.
Total internal reflection requires angle of refraction r' in air to be greater than critical angle θ_c.
Critical angle θ_c is given by θ_c = sin^(-1)(n_air/n_sphere).
Angle of incidence i' inside sphere is related to angle i in air by geometry.
Angle i' is angle between incoming light ray and normal at point of incidence.
Angle of refraction r' in air is angle between outgoing light ray and normal at point of emergence.
Angle i'' is related to angle i' by geometry of triangle formed by light rays and normals.
Sum of angles in triangle is 180 degrees, related by refractive indices and sphere geometry.
For total internal reflection, angle of refraction i'' must be greater than critical angle θ_c: sin i'' > n_air/n_sphere.
Angle i'' is related to angle i by refractive indices and sphere radius.
Critical angle θ_c is angle for which light barely escapes sphere without reflection.
If angle of incidence i is large enough, angle of refraction i'' will cause total reflection.
Condition for total internal reflection depends on refractive indices and sphere geometry.
Generally, if angle of incidence i is large enough, light will be totally reflected.
Final answer: Yes, light will be totally reflected.
